bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to James M. Phalen, August 7, 1927

div1.p: Laura Carter provides Phalen with biographical information on Henry Carter and describes his temperament.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to James M. Phalen, August 7, 1927
div1.opener:
Biographic
Phalen, Col. James
for
Am. Dictionary of Biography
“Dunlora.” Box 453,
Charlottesville, Virginia.
August 7, 1927.
Colonel James M. Phalen,
Medical Corps, U. S. Army,
Librarian, Army Medical Library,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Colonel Phalen:
div1.p:
I am so sorry for the delay in sending you the biographic data for which you
wrote me, concerning my Father, Dr. Henry Rose Carter. I had a relapse after acknowledg-
ing your letter and am just “out of the woods” again. As to your questions:

list.item:
1:
(a) Birthplace: Clifton plantation. Caroline County, Virginia.
(b) If in rural community, near what town or village was it?-- Nearest
town was Fredericksburg, 28 miles distant.

2:
(a) Name of Father,? Henry Rose Carter.
(b) Maiden name of Mother? Emma Coleman.

3:
(a) Origin of Carter family, whether English, Scotch etc.? English. Lords
the Manor of Garston in Hertfordshire, at time of emigration to America.
(b) Approximate date of arrival of family in America? 1649.

4:
(a) Maiden name of Mrs. Carter (wife of above)? Laura Eugenia (Van) Hook.
(The “Van” is put in brackets, because, after using it for several generations after their
arrival in America (Pennsylvania) the family dropped it on moving first to Maryland and
thentoto Illinois. In order to be more American, I suppose.
(b) Place and date of marriage?: Cairo, Illinois, September 29, 1880.
(c) Residence of Mrs. Carter at time of marriage? Cairo, Illinois.
5: Number of children: Three: Henry Rose: Laura Armistead: Edward Champe.

div1.p:
As to # 3: Father was considered more like the Colemans (his Mother's people) and
the Roses than the Carters. The Carters were steady, dependable, “County people,” of more
than average ability The Coleman's were brilliant intellectually, a
“steadfast” at the same time a rather annual combination. The Rose Father's both
Gill Carter of Mine Hill married Mary Rose) are Scotch, (from Kilravock
Nairno (Highlanders, you see)). Father's temperament was far more Celtic than Anglo-
Saxon (in its sensitiveness: appreciation of poetry: nature: art etc) although he was as
“steadfast” and enduring as a man could be.

I hope this is about what you wish to know. However, if I am well enough, I ex-
pect to run down to Washington on business sometime this week and, if I do so, will call
you up and see if I can be of any further help to you in the work you are honoring us in
doing.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter.
